Text_Numeracy: I was at the hospital with a friend looking at the patient chart when the doctor came in and was asking questions and commenting on the norms of the tests that he had seen. There was a comment on serum glucose levels. The doctor made a note to recheck the levels. When he left I looked at the value and asked my friend if she was diabetic, she commented that she merely had a few elevated blood glucose levels. She said that her doctor was not concerned with the levels, but I asked her to ask about the actual values and maybe get a second opinion. Maybe she just needs to watch her carbohydrate intake more closely. The doctor rechecked the levels a few days later and the values were still elevated.

Text_Numeracy: A deep understanding of health and medical issues is demonstrated in multiple ways throughout the course of life, in everyday decisions as well as major health issues. In working with a doctor and dietician to develop an eating plan that meets health and wellness goals and makes allowances for potential medical issues that could be impacted by what is eaten is one example of knowledge of health and medical issues. Another more serious issue can also demonstrate an understanding of medical issues. In living with the knowledge of a family history of colon cancer, the understanding that regular colonoscopy screenings are a necessity and the risk of colon cancer being inherited and in needing to undergo more frequent screenings at a certain age and until the screening results come back negative for a specific number of years indicates an understanding of not only colon cancer being a hereditary disease but understanding the medical necessity and guidelines of care that must be followed.

Text_Numeracy: One significant experience that demonstrated my knowledge of health and medical issues was when I had to manage my medication regimen. With multiple prescriptions to keep track of, I took the initiative to educate myself about potential interactions, side effects, and the importance of adherence to my prescribed schedule. This understanding not only helped me optimize my physical activity routine by timing my workouts with my medications but also allowed me to have informed discussions with my psychologist about any changes in my mental state or physical performance. It reinforced the connection between my physical health, mental well-being, and how they can be managed through informed medication use.
Text_Anxiety: I don’t typically feel anxiety when meeting doctors, but I do find it a bit uncomfortable sometimes. I suppose the uncertainty of what might come from the visit—like unexpected results or the need to adjust my medications—can occasionally create a sense of unease, but I usually manage to maintain my composure. I focus on the positives, like keeping track of my health and the benefits of regular check-ups.
Text_TrustPhys: I don't have a primary care physician, but when it comes to doctors in general, I have a mix of trust and skepticism. Overall, I approach each interaction with a level of caution, balancing trust in their expertise with a desire to advocate for my own health.

Text_Numeracy:
Describing a singular medical experience is very complicated and I will provide examples for a few different events. 

A few years ago, my mother had a brain aneurism. I was aware of how serious this was and understood a need to get her to the hospital quickly. 

About four years ago, my father had a heart attack and triple by-pass surgery. Again, I was aware of how serious this was and knew the steps my father would be facing afterwards. 

Also, close friends have dealt with kidney stones, herniated discs, knee replacements, childbirth (5), and now a stage 4 cancer diagnosis. 

I know that I am not a medical professional, but I do believe that I have gained a lot of medical knowledge due to my experiences discussed above.

Text_Numeracy:
The most important thing I can think of is the day I found out my husband had colon cancer. I had taken off all summer from working to 1) support our daughter who was graduating high school and 2) save money to travel to hear my husband get his doctorate. Then, on the very last day of summer before returning to work, he came to me and told me he had surgery. He was in severe pain and discomfort. He finally toldme he was going to the doctor. I waited and waited. Finally, he texted me that he had made it to the doctor and I asked if I should come - YES!  So I went and when he told me what was wrong, I was devastated.

I don't think I reacted well to the news. I was in shock and disbelief and didn't handle it well at all. 

In situations like this, I really need someone else to handle me because I am the worst at knowing how to help someone else. I certainly didn't need to be worried about.

We are okay - we have handled it. 

Just hard at the time.

She also has to start a low potassium diet.

Text_Numeracy: One experience that demonstrated my knowledge of health and medical issues was when I decided to research the various prescription medications I was taking. I came across a lot of information about potential side effects and drug interactions, which led me to have a more informed conversation with my psychiatrist. This reinforced my commitment to living in the best possible health and being proactive in managing my well-being.

Text_TrustPhys: I don't have a primary care physician specifically, but I do have mixed feelings about doctors in general. On one hand, I value their expertise and knowledge, especially when it comes to managing my prescription medications and ensuring my active lifestyle is supported. However, I often feel that the connection and communication can sometimes be lacking. It’s important for me to have a doctor who really understands my commitment to health and fitness, and sometimes I find that they may not fully appreciate my perspective. Trust is built through experience, and I believe that communication and a shared understanding of my health goals are crucial for that trust.
